publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: with non-human being(s), thus with the animals, finally with a chicken, Pār. || At this time, it (=the sin) will disappear. With the magic creatures, (and non-human being), even that indeed
he does the connection involving sexual pleasure, step by step, concerning all (the cases), Sthūlātyaya. || Buddha was staying in Rājagṛha. A monk named Dhanika
Ein Mönch, Dhanika [mit] Namen, holte sich ohne Erlaubnis des Königs Ajātaśatru [wtl. ohne von König A. mit einer Erlaubnis versehen zu sein] Holz.
A monk, Dhanika [by] name, got himself wood without king Ajātaśatru's consent [lit. without being provided with the permission by king A.].
took away wood of the king Ajātaśatru without permission. Buddha heard and blamed. || But which monk,

Welcher Mönch aber Nichtgegebenes in einer Weise, die als Diebstahl zählt [wtl. Diebstahl als Zählung habend], nehmen sollte, so dass ein König ihn auf Grund solchen Nehmens von Nichtgegebenem ergreifen und ihn schlagen oder ihn binden oder ihn des Landes verweisen oder so zu ihm sprechen würde [wtl. auf Grund wie beschaffenen Nehmens von Nichtgegebenem ein König, ihn ergriffen habend, ihn schlagen ... würde]: "Du bist ein Dieb, du bist töricht, du bist dumm [bzw. du bist ein Tor, du bist ein Dummkopf], du bist ein Räuber!" - ein Mönch, der auf solche Weise Nichtgegebenes nimmt, auch dieser Mönch ist pārājika [d.h. eines Pārājika-Vergehens schuldig] [und] darf nicht mit [der Gemeinde] [zusammen]bleiben.

Which[ever] monk, however, should take a thing not given in a manner that counts as theft [lit. having theft as counting], so that a king would, because of such taking of a thing not given, would seize him and beat him or bind him or banish him from the country or speak to him thus [lit. because of such conditioned taking of a thing not given, having seized him, would beat him ...]: “You are a thief, you are foolish, you are stupid [OR: you are a fool, you are a stupe], you are a robber!” – a monk, who, in such a manner, takes a thing not given, this monk also is pārājika [i.e. guilty of a pārājika offence] [and] must not remain with [the community].
as calculation of a thief, takes away for himself what has not been given, in which way, because of carrying off what has not been given, the king, after arresting him, would beat him,
or would bind him, or would banish him from the country, or would tell him just thus: 'you are a thief, you are foolish,
you are mistaken, you are a robber', in such way, the monk taking away what has not been given, this monk also
is deprived. One should not reside with him. || How is the sin here? One moves a heavy thing (in the same way) with the intention of thief,

[Wenn] er einen schweren Gegenstand (in) [irgend]einer (Weise) in diebischer Absicht von einem Ort entfernt [wtl. fortbewegt], auch nur einen Finger[breit], [und zwar] von den [folgenden Orten:] ..., so überschreitet er den Bereich [der Verordnung] ...

[If] he, with larcenous intent, moves a heavy object (in) a[ny] (way) from a place, if only [by] a finger['s breadth], [more precisely,] from the [following places:] ..., then he transgresses the area [of the regulation] ...
from the place, even (in the distance of) a finger. || From these places, from the roof, from the cell, on the tree, on the earth, (inside the earth), in the sky,

in the air, in the water, in the boat, from the chariot, from the private land (?), one proclaims for himself on the earth (= one makes the landmarks for himself), one goes beyond or turns the village,

one gathers thieves for himself, those without foot, the two-footed, four-footed, and many-footed, one suppresses a theft, one destroys the dress (= one takes away the dress), one covers up a thief for oneself,
(if) one has put (something) in secret, beginning with it, (if) one does this sort of damage, or one orders to do,

If it is done secretly, [and] he does in some way harm to another in a com- parable manner, or causes [somebody else] to do [so], and the place (?) is full, then it is a pārājika offence. If the place is not full, then it is a grave (sthūla) offence. [If it is] somehow from a human with respect to an impor- tant [possession], then it is a pārājika offence. [If it is] like that, [but] from a non-human or an animal, then it is a grave (sthūla) offence. [If it is] somehow from a human with respect to an unimportant possession, then it is a grave (sthūla) offence. [If it is] like that, [but] from a non-human or an animal, then it is a duṣkṛta offence.
(if) the condition is filled, Pār. || (If) the condition is not filled, Sthūlātyaya. || In which case, from human being, because of a heavy thing, Pār. ||

In this case, from non-human being and from an animal, Sthūlātyaya. || In which case, from human being, because of a light thing, Sthūlātyaya. || In this case, from non-human being and from an animal, Duṣkṛta. ||
Buddha was staying on the bank of the river Phalgumatī. In the place of the forest, he taught the impurity to the monks. These monks ///

p.note: According to 96 "[w]ritten in medium ductus and very clearly preserved, the manuscript is complete".
(a)mānuṣempa (first instance): the akṣara nu is added below the line.
amānuṣempa (second instance): the whole word amānuṣempa is added under the previous word; there is a cross over the "•" marking the addition.
mäṅkau: an ink rest makes the second akṣara look a bit like ṅkṣau.
mā-wṣaṣlempa: for wsaṣlempa; actually, the upper part of the ṣ looks a bit like the upper part of an s.
iprerne: the upper left stroke of the i is too long.

a1. (a)mānuṣempa (first instance): the akṣara nu is added below the line.

a1. amānuṣempa (second instance): the whole word amānuṣempa is added under the previous word; there is a cross over the "•" marking the addition.

a7. mäṅkau: an ink rest makes the second akṣara look a bit like ṅkṣau.

a7. mā-wṣaṣlempa: for wsaṣlempa; actually, the upper part of the ṣ looks a bit like the upper part of an s.

b2. iprerne: the upper left stroke of the i is too long.

a1 with non-human being(s), thus with the animals, finally with a chicken, Pār. || At this time, it (=the sin) will disappear. With the magic creatures, (and non-human being), even that indeed a2 he does the connection involving sexual pleasure, step by step, concerning all (the cases), Sthūlātyaya. || Buddha was staying in Rājagṛha. A monk named Dhanika a3 took away wood of the king Ajātaśatru without permission. Buddha heard and blamed. || But which monk, a4 as calculation of a thief, takes away for himself what has not been given, in which way, because of carrying off what has not been given, the king, after arresting him, would beat him, a5 or would bind him, or would banish him from the country, or would tell him just thus: 'you are a thief, you are foolish, a6 you are mistaken, you are a robber', in such way, the monk taking away what has not been given, this monk also a7 is deprived. One should not reside with him. || How is the sin here? One moves a heavy thing (in the same way) with the intention of thief, b1 from the place, even (in the distance of) a finger. || From these places, from the roof, from the cell, on the tree, on the earth, (inside the earth), in the sky, b2 in the air, in the water, in the boat, from the chariot, from the private land (?), one proclaims for himself on the earth (= one makes the landmarks for himself), one goes beyond or turns the village, b3 one gathers thieves for himself, those without foot, the two-footed, four-footed, and many-footed, one suppresses a theft, one destroys the dress (= one takes away the dress), one covers up a thief for oneself, b4 (if) one has put (something) in secret, beginning with it, (if) one does this sort of damage, or one orders to do, b5 (if) the condition is filled, Pār. || (If) the condition is not filled, Sthūlātyaya. || In which case, from human being, because of a heavy thing, Pār. || b6 In this case, from non-human being and from an animal, Sthūlātyaya. || In which case, from human being, because of a light thing, Sthūlātyaya. || In this case, from non-human being and from an animal, Duṣkṛta. || b7 Buddha was staying on the bank of the river Phalgumatī. In the place of the forest, he taught the impurity to the monks. These monks ///

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
b4-6 If it is done secretly, [and] he does in some way harm to another in a com-
parable manner, or causes [somebody else] to do [so], and the place (?) is full, then it is a pārājika offence. If the place is not full, then it is a grave
(sthūla) offence. [If it is] somehow from a human with respect to an impor-
tant [possession], then it is a pārājika offence. [If it is] like that, [but] from a non-human or an animal, then it is a grave (sthūla) offence. [If it is] somehow
from a human with respect to an unimportant possession, then it is a grave
(sthūla) offence. [If it is] like that, [but] from a non-human or an animal, then
it is a duṣkṛta offence.		 336


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a2-3 Ein Mönch, Dhanika [mit] Namen, holte sich ohne Erlaubnis des Königs Ajātaśatru [wtl. ohne von König A. mit einer Erlaubnis versehen zu sein] Holz. 400
a3-7 Welcher Mönch aber Nichtgegebenes in einer Weise, die als Diebstahl zählt [wtl. Diebstahl als Zählung habend], nehmen sollte, so dass ein König ihn auf Grund solchen Nehmens von Nichtgegebenem ergreifen und ihn schlagen oder ihn binden oder ihn des Landes verweisen oder so zu ihm sprechen würde [wtl. auf Grund wie beschaffenen Nehmens von Nichtgegebenem ein König, ihn ergriffen habend, ihn schlagen ... würde]: "Du bist ein Dieb, du bist töricht, du bist dumm [bzw. du bist ein Tor, du bist ein Dummkopf], du bist ein Räuber!" - ein Mönch, der auf solche Weise Nichtgegebenes nimmt, auch dieser Mönch ist pārājika [d.h. eines Pārājika-Vergehens schuldig] [und] darf nicht mit [der Gemeinde] [zusammen]bleiben. 361-2
a7-b2 [Wenn] er einen schweren Gegenstand (in) [irgend]einer (Weise) in diebischer Absicht von einem Ort entfernt [wtl. fortbewegt], auch nur einen Finger[breit], [und zwar] von den [folgenden Orten:] ..., so überschreitet er den Bereich [der Verordnung] ... 299, 412


[[Broomhead I]]: 101-102 translates:

a1 With non-human ones. And even with animals, and even with a chicken, [there is] pārājika. At his time he disappeared. With the magical creations and with the non-humans. Somehow however ...

a2 he performs the sexual act. Step by step with all [he does it] Sthūlāñca. The Buddha was in Rājagṛha. A monk named Dhanika

a3 fetched wood without the permission of king Ajātaśatru. The Buddha heard this and scolded him. Whichever monk should do ... without [permission] having been given

a4 takes [it] thievishly as a theft category. In what state. Not given, by that which is carried. The king having seized him he beat him and he had him

a5 bound and expelled him from the country. Or he said thus to him. "You are a thief [and] you are a rogue.

a6 You are a deceiver. You are a robber thus. In just such a way [You are] a monk [who permission] not having been given [are] carrying [away]. Also

a7 this monk is subdued. Not with asaṃvāsa. Here is a crime as it is if he removes likewise a heavy thing with thieving

b1 intention even [if it be] only a finger's breadth away. From these places, from this mat, from this cave, on this tree, on the earth ... in the air.

b2 In the air, in the water, on a ship, from a gānaṣṭhaṃ, from a bhāraṣṭhaṃ, on the earth [it is] proclaimed. He strides over the realm and converts [people]. Thieves [he]

b3 gathers. Without feet, two-footed, four-footed, many footed ... is oppressed [and] ... causes to disappear. He takes thieves [unto himself].

b4 If it is done secretly. In like manner some kind of harm is caused to another, or he orders it to be caused.

b5 If the matter is [then] pārājika. If the matter is not [then there is] stu. Insofar as it is from one man with respect to an important [possession] [then it is] pārājika.

b6 That is why [with regard] to non-humans [and] animals [it is] stu. Just as [with regard] to humans with respect to an unimportant (trivial) possession [it is] stu. For this reason [with regard] to non-humans and animals [it is] du.

b7 The Buddha was beside the river Phalgumatī, in a wooded place. He was lecturing to the monks on aśubhabhāvanā meditation. These monks ...
According to [[Broomhead I]]: 96 "[w]ritten in medium ductus and very clearly preserved, the manuscript is complete".

div.p: <citedRange>101-102</citedRange></bibl> translates: </p><p>a1 With non-human ones. And even with animals, and even with a chicken, [there is] pārājika. At his time he disappeared. With the magical creations and with the non-humans. Somehow however ... </p><p>a2 he performs the sexual act. Step by step with all [he does it] Sthūlāñca. The Buddha was in Rājagṛha. A monk named Dhanika </p><p>a3 fetched wood without the permission of king Ajātaśatru. The Buddha heard this and scolded him. Whichever monk should do ... without [permission] having been given</p><p>a4 takes [it] thievishly as a theft category. In what state. Not given, by that which is carried. The king having seized him he beat him and he had him </p><p>a5 bound and expelled him from the country. Or he said thus to him. "You are a thief [and] you are a rogue. </p><p>a6 You are a deceiver. You are a robber thus. In just such a way [You are] a monk [who permission] not having been given [are] carrying [away]. Also </p><p>a7 this monk is subdued. Not with asaṃvāsa. Here is a crime as it is if he removes likewise a heavy thing with thieving </p><p>b1 intention even [if it be] only a finger's breadth away. From these places, from this mat, from this cave, on this tree, on the earth ... in the air. </p><p>b2 In the air, in the water, on a ship, from a gānaṣṭhaṃ, from a bhāraṣṭhaṃ, on the earth [it is] proclaimed. He strides over the realm and converts [people]. Thieves [he] </p><p>b3 gathers. Without feet, two-footed, four-footed, many footed ... is oppressed [and] ... causes to disappear. He takes thieves [unto himself]. </p><p>b4 If it is done secretly. In like manner some kind of harm is caused to another, or he orders it to be caused. </p><p>b5 If the matter is [then] pārājika. If the matter is not [then there is] stu. Insofar as it is from one man with respect to an important [possession] [then it is] pārājika. </p><p>b6 That is why [with regard] to non-humans [and] animals [it is] stu. Just as [with regard] to humans with respect to an unimportant (trivial) possession [it is] stu. For this reason [with regard] to non-humans and animals [it is] du. </p><p>b7 The Buddha was beside the river Phalgumatī, in a wooded place. He was lecturing to the monks on aśubhabhāvanā meditation. These monks ... </p></project_comment>
